question_text: I set up a limited liability company in 2015. My business suffered greatly during the Covid-19 pandemic, and it still hasn’t recovered yet. I fell into arrears, and one of my suppliers submitted a winding-up petition against my business. A friend of mine is willing to invest money in my company. Do I have good chances of avoiding a liquidation order if my friend commits to pumping money into my business?

The key points here are the grounds for winding-up under the Insolvency Act 1986, especially sections 122 and 123 about inability to pay debts. The user needs to show that the pandemic directly caused their financial troubles and that the investment would resolve the insolvency. Another case, Petitioner v Company [2022], states that the court must be satisfied that without Covid's impact, the company wouldn't be insolvent. So the user must demonstrate that the arrears are due to the pandemic, not other factors. But the court will look at whether the company can become solvent. In Byblos Bank SAL v Al-Khudhairy, future funding without concrete commitments wasn't enough. Procedurally, the user should oppose the petition under CIGA, showing Covid's impact and the investment as a solution. They might need to file evidence like financial statements, the investment agreement, and a turnaround plan. The court will assess if the company can pay its debts post-investment. If the supplier's debt is disputed, they can argue that, but if it's undisputed, the focus is on solvency.
